abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, yet, quality at entry was
            rated as marginally satisfactory. Four main lessons
            stipulate the following. First, given water supply and
            sewerage projects play a central role in reaching the
            Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), the project should have
            been more precise in identifying the number of project
            beneficiaries, instead of focusing on the implementation of
            the large capital investment program, in contrast to the
            ultimate objectives of the project: to improve the
            environmental and health situation in Mumbai. It would have
            been more effective to provide benefits to the population,
            had it considered how the Mumbai population would receive
            water service; how the wastewater would be collected, how it
            would be transported to treatment works, and finally
            disposed of. Refocusing the project as suggested, would
            likely have resulted in the inclusion of efforts to manage
            water demand, thus minimizing the quantity of wastewater
            produced. Second, successive Bank projects to the same
            borrower, should make an effort to advance in parallel
            between capital investment financing, and policy reform. In
            this project (the fourth project to Mumbai) its design could
            have promoted a closer integration between the water supply
            and sewerage sections of the Water Supply and Sewerage
            Department (WSSD), and the related measures to raise the
            autonomy and accountability of its activities. As it
            happened, the project design did not aim at reforming the
            WSSD organization, to update its tariff policies, to set
            performance standards, and to provide staff incentives in
            reaching targets. Third, the success of the slum sanitation
            program (SSP) confirms once again the need to improve the
            health, and well-being of the poorest populations: an
            organization in a demand driven approach shows the program
            can be expected to be sustainable, and yield important
            demonstration effects. And, fourth, the importance of
            quality at entry, demonstrates how by surmounting
            objectives, as well as limitations, can fully turn a poorly
            prepared project into success.
